utterances: The two people I most respected and looked up to as an aspiring rapper were both from where I was from and they were both murdered.
And now, here I am, Google searching my name and finding out that I, too, am dead.

I was flattered that I made enough of an impact to get people on the Internet writing blogs and forums about me, and if I really had been killed, it looks like my funeral would have a pretty good turnout.
But on a more serious note, I have had my own real-life brushes with the angel of death.
Bullets have traveled in my direction more than once.
(Soundbite of music)
(Rapping) Ay (unintelligible) it's the Bay.
Everybody both ways, everybody scoop (unintelligible)...
I was blessed to safely make it out of those situations.

Other people close to me have not been as fortunate, and because of that, I know the unexplainable feeling one gets in their stomach as they pass by and say their last goodbyes to buddies and friends and family.
I don't want who I hold close to me to get that gut-wrenching feeling while looking down at my own lifeless body.
(Soundbite of music)
(Rapping) I got to eat.
I got to survive...
More painful for me than my own narrow escapes are the nightmares my mom has told me about.
She's dreamt the police knocking on her door and delivering that dreadful news that no mother wants to hear.
The most I can do as a son is reassure her I'll be fine and pray that it is true.
I'm pursuing a dream, and the people who have done it before me have tragically met a fate that is all too common in this world.

But this is the reality of the life I fell in love with: Rap starts in the streets, and unfortunately, regardless of a person's status, fans or income, it can have a bloody ending in those same streets.
I'm going to do what I can in my own life to keep rumors like those about my death: just rumors.
(Soundbite of song ""I Get It"")
(Rapping) Green light, I go.
I get, get it, get it.
On top of the scrape, I hit it, hit it, hit it.
Black beanie flipped backwards...
Youth Radio's Orlando Campbell, aka Roach Gigz.
He's very much alive in San Francisco.
(Soundbite of song ""I Get It"")
(Rapping) In the building.
Packing, whatcha lacking?
Lot of talk, no action.
You acting, we blapping.
It's cracking.
Please trust For the turf, we bust.
Go dumb, that's a must.
We ride the yellow bus, like the kids with cross eyes.
Stunners on my face, can't see my eyes.
Tie-dyed pills like skittles, real little.
I'm a do it with drizzle, pop you like a thizzle.
Got gold in my dental, and I'm feeling real bossy.

Papa don't boss me...
We're very much alive, too.
More to come on Day to Day.
MADELEINE BRAND, host.
This is Day to Day.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
ALEX COHEN, host
And I'm Alex Cohen.
Coming up, if homes aren't selling in Florida why are builders planning a new development in an environmentally sensitive area that's long been off limits.
But first, President Bush has just about a month left, not much time for his administration to issue new regulations.
It will issue a new one this week though and it's one that will please anti-abortion activist.
NPR's Julie Rovner is here to explain.
And Julie what is this new rule?

What we're expecting is that this is a rule that will allow people who have moral objections to abortion or perhaps any other reproductive-related issue to not participate in any of those of activities.
These are health-care providers?

These are health-care providers but they're not just health care providers, not just doctors and nurses but pharmacists, clerks, perhaps whole hospitals or entire health plans would be covered by these regulations.
So what would that mean that they would not have to perform abortions?
They'd not - they wouldn't have to issue contraception?
Yes, all of the above.

They would not only, not have to participate in or perform abortions or contraceptions, but what's really at issue here is that they wouldn't have to refer patient to want these services to other people who would perform these services.
And that's really at the nub of what's going on here.
There are currently on the books lots of laws that already protect health care providers from having to violate their moral or religious beliefs.
Some of them date back to the early 1970s before Roe v.
Wade, before abortion was even legal.

But what these regulations would do is basically expand that beyond doctors and nurses to basically anyone who's associated with health care and say that, that no one has to do basically anything that violates any of their beliefs even if they're only tangentially related to the act of providing health care services.
So why does the Bush administration want this new rule?
I'd say the vast majority are much more concerned about how this plays out and the legal proceedings that we're doing.
You know, this was an act of five individuals, you know?
This was not sanctioned by the tribal government and not sanctioned by the managing body that the Makah Whaling Commission.
Do you think it's fair to say that the Makah living now would have no living memory of whaling except for the one hunt in 1999?
There had been no hunt before that for 70 years.
Is this a tradition that has - it's gone?
Unidentified Woman #9: Yes.

Porter Goss told USA Today that his agency collects information in, quote, ""a variety of unique and innovative ways, all of which are legal and none of which,"" he says, ""are torture."" To get a sense of just how fine the line may be, Goss contends the CIA has gathered information with techniques that would be banned under a Senate proposal to prevent what it calls cruel, inhumane or degrading treatment.
The debate over torture continues at the same time that Europeans want to know what's been happening on their soil.
Very little has been revealed since The Washington Post first reported that the US held prisoners there.
Today, we have an update about what's known about detention centers in Europe, what's not known and what's being done about it.
We'll start with Tom Malinowski.
He's with Human Rights Watch, which found evidence that the United States might have taken prisoners to Poland and Romania.
Well, we have been able to look at the flight logs of a number of aircraft that the CIA has used in part to ferry prisoners around the world.

There are several flights to those countries, one in particular in September of 2003 at just around the time when we've been told by other sources that several high-level al-Qaeda prisoners were taken out of Afghanistan, and this flight in particular leaves Kabul, goes to a small isolated rural airfield in northeastern Poland that happens to be attractant to a Polish intelligence facility, then goes on to a military airfield in Romania, makes its way to Guantanamo Bay.
Very probably a detainee flight.
Can't be explained by refueling.
Why is it very probably a detainee flight?
Well, because it begins in Kabul and ends up in Guantanamo.
Certainly suggests that this involved detainee transport.

And again it's been suggested to us by other sources that several of the more well-known al-Qaeda leadership figures, for example, Khalid Sheik Mohammed, were in Afghanistan until September of 2003 and then left.
Now we should mention that a number of people, just as a hobby if nothing else, tracked the comings and goings of various planes with various tail numbers.
I assume that's part of this.
That's the original source.
I mean, I think it's sort of a funny story.
Some members of Congress have expressed outrage that the cover of the secret CIA operation was broken by The Washington Post.
In fact, it was broken by a bunch of folks who as a hobby go to airports and watch planes take off and land, write down the serial numbers and put them on the Internet.
The CIA didn't count on that apparently, and with that information, some journalists were able to obtain the flight records of these planes and the information is there for everybody to see.
Do you think that this could only happen with the knowledge of the host governments?
I don't think it could happen without the knowledge of at least some people in the host governments.

I would be surprised if the United States had kept people for any period of time in Poland without the president of Poland being informed and without people at least in the intelligence services of those countries knowing about it, although presumably knowledge could have been limited to a small number of people.
Tom Malinowski of Human Rights Watch, thanks very much.
Thank you.
In Washington State, the illegal killing of a gray whale this past weekend has divided members of the Makah tribe.
On Saturday morning, five members of the tribe set out in motorboats from Neah Bay, Washington.
About a mile from shore, the hunters launched harpoons into a gray whale then tried to finish it off with a high-powered rifle.
It took hours for the whale to die.
By then, the Coast Guard officers were on the scene.
The Makah Tribal Council was quick to denounce the hunt.
The tribe has been fighting in court for nearly a decade to regain its whaling rights.
In 1999, the tribe was granted a waiver for one whale hunt.
It was the first hunt in 70 years.
Tribal council member Micah McCarty came to Washington, D.C.
this week to talk to members of Congress and try to undo the damage caused by this unauthorized kill.
When he came by our studio today, I asked him about his reaction when he first heard about the incident.
Immediately, you know, I received a report from a community member, the cell phone number of a Coast Guard commander on base.
When I did reach him, he indicated that there were five Makahs being detained as we speak.
I asked the status of the whale, he said it's bleeding.
It's mortally wounded and it's still kind of swimming around, and it's still attached to a now empty boat with the rifle sitting in the boat.
And I explained to him that this is a serious issue not just for the Makah Tribal Council with this tribal violation, but this is an issue of humaneness.
This animal needs to be euthanized.
Did that happen?
We, again, made a formal request by our own tribal officials that, you know, we're prepared to euthanize, we had an approved tribal marksman ready to do the job on, on permission from the feds.
And by the time that had come, you know, had been hours and the whale died of its own wounds.
One of the men on this boat, Wayne Johnson, sounds completely unrepentant for what he did.
He said, I should have done it years ago.
What happens to these men?
They're now in tribal custody, they were taken into tribal custody.
What happens to them now?
Well, we are cooperating with the federal investigation.
My assumption is that charges will be filed.
What kind of charges?
Certainly, the biggest issue if the violation of our Gray Whale Management Plan.
And that's where the stiffest penalties lie and what we have to prosecute with.
They're looking at up to one year in jail, $5,000 fine.
But the hardest part is the potential for a loss of treaty rights for up to three years.
And for a community that depends so much on the sea for livelihood, some of these people have families that they support as fishermen, as tribal fishermen.
And, you know, they're looking at a very strong likelihood of not being able to exercise that treaty right.
